ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Traumatic Tympanic Membrane Perforation
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of direct trauma (branch puncture), flat conductive hearing loss, and Type B tympanogram with large ear canal volume (7.1 mL).

ordered_list.rationale_short: Assess hearing sensitivity and type of hearing loss.
Evaluate speech reception thresholds and word recognition abilities.
Assess middle ear status and tympanic membrane integrity.
Evaluate reflex pathways to cross-check conductive pathology.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The right ear is within normal limits. The left ear exhibits a mild-to-moderate flat conductive hearing loss with excellent word recognition. Tympanometry reveals a large ear canal volume in the left ear, confirming a tympanic membrane perforation. Acoustic reflexes are absent in conditions involving the left ear due to the conductive pathology.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right ear normal (PTA 10 dB HL). Left ear flat mild-to-moderate conductive loss (PTA 32 dB HL) with air-bone gap approx 30-35 dB.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right SRT 10 dB HL, WRS 96%. Left SRT 35 dB HL, WRS 100%.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Right Type A (normal). Left Type B (flat) with large ear canal volume (7.1 mL), consistent with perforation.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Right ipsilateral present (90-95 dB HL). Left ipsilateral, right contralateral, and left contralateral absent.

proposed_items: Referral to ENT for surgical evaluation
counseling_actions: Explain the conductive nature of the hearing loss due to the eardrum perforation
Reassure that inner ear nerve function is normal
Advise on keeping the ear dry to prevent infection
Discuss the recommendation for surgical repair

escalation.rationale_short: Evaluation of large traumatic tympanic membrane perforation for potential surgical repair.

follow_up_plan.objective: Determine if hearing improves following surgical intervention.

expected_outcome: Patient followed up with an ENT specialist regarding the perforated tympanic membrane.
It was determined that the perforation was large, and surgical intervention was recommended.
Imaging studies were performed and surgery was scheduled.
